subject: Gardening
title: Electric Signals in Plants
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Electric Signals in Plants.

hook.text: Venus flytraps count. They only snap shut after two hair triggers are touched within 20 seconds.

buildup.text: Each trigger hair sends an electrical signalâ€”an action potentialâ€”similar to signals in animal neurons.

discovery.text: Plants use electrical signals to coordinate rapid responses. Wounding a leaf triggers signals across the whole plant.

twist.text: These signals travel at up to 40 meters per second in some speciesâ€”slower than nerves but far faster than hormones.

climax.text: Plants have an electrical signaling system that predates animal nervous systems by hundreds of millions of years.

punchline.text: Plants wired themselves before animals had nerves.

quiz.question: Why does a Venus flytrap require two trigger hairs to be touched?
options: To count touches and avoid wasting energy on non-prey stimuli like raindrops
Each hair controls one half of the trap mechanism
The first touch primes a chemical reaction that the second touch completes
